If the U.S. attorney in New Jersey has the authority to prosecute this, the U.S. Attorney in New York can't say, oh, and by the way I bind all the other U.S. Attorneys.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: Well, the U.S. Attorney in New York could -- presumably that U.S. Attorney will know who else might have jurisdiction over the underlying conduct and would go and get an agreement from those other U.S. attorneys.
But unless the U.S. Attorney does that, under one approach the agreement bars only the contracting entity.
But even if you're right--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But do I understand your position that in this particular case the U.S. Attorney could have entered into a settlement agreement that would have bound the Respondent?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --We actually don't think that that's right, Justice Stevens.

We think that in fact the U.S. Attorney did not bind the Respondent, but we don't think it could have bound the Respondent, and it goes back to my answer to Justice Sotomayor, because Respondent here is representing the D.C. court system.
And so the U.S. Attorney really would have had--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You draw a distinction between the D.C. Circuit -- the D.C. and the United States?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --Yes.
Ultimately the D.C. court system is an actor that is wielding United States authority.
But it's a very different--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But you would agree, I take it, that the attorney for the District of Columbia could have bound Respondent?
Somebody could bind Respondent without Respondent even knowing about it, that's what I'm asking.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --I think only the D.C. court could have prevented Respondent from going forward.
I think that the U.S.--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And I have to agree with you that to accept this argument that the prosecutor here is an agent just of the court, just of the D.C. court, not an agent of the executive?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --If -- who would you like the person be an agent of, Justice Scalia?
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, I'm not making the argument.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Usually we have questions the other way.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: I apologize.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I don't know that courts have ever asserted that they themselves have the power to prosecute.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: Well, I do think that that's the situation that we find in Young, where a court appoints a person to prosecute a contempt on behalf of the court.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Not on behalf of the court.
On behalf of the government, and that's why Young said you should offer it first to the United States Attorney, and only if he won't bring it, then you can appoint somebody else to bring it.
But the -- the prosecutor is not the court.
My God.
What a terrible situation.
The prosecutor's the court, the judge is the court?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: Well, I do think Young is different, Justice Scalia, because Young was a separation of powers case.
This case is not because it arises in D.C. In Young, absolutely the judge has to go to the U.S. Attorney's Office first.
But that's not the case here, because normal separation of powers principles are not in application in D.C.--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Isn't it the case that only the U.S. Attorney can prosecute for this crime?
Could the D.C. attorney general or whatever the name of it, what, counsel, prosecute for this felony?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --Justice Scalia, I don't believe that is entirely clear.
I think that the court could ask the D.C. Attorney General to prosecute the crime in the same way that the court in Young asked the U.S. Attorney's Office.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Because it's all up to the court; the court's the big prosecutor, right?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: Well, just as -- I know you dissented in Young, Justice Scalia.
But just as the court in Young goes to the U.S. Attorney first and when the court is told no the court can appoint its own independent prosecutor, essentially that's what is happening here.
The court is appointing--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, if there were a finding of innocent, or not guilty, by this prosecutor, could the official prosecutor then prosecute again, or would there be double jeopardy?
If you are saying they are somehow separate, does the double jeopardy clause apply?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --Well, this Court held in Dixon that the double jeopardy clause does apply, because they're all exercising power--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, but that was the same authority.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --Yes, and they all are exercising power from the United States.
Dixon involved this very statute.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: So you don't think this is a Bartkiss-like case, like Bartkiss v. Illinois?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: I -- I am not familiar with that case, Justice Kennedy, but I do think that the double jeopardy clause--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: That a State prosecution doesn't bar a later Federal prosecution.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --Yes, that's exactly right, because ultimately all of these power are exercising power that comes from the same source, which is the United States Government.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Is your argument the broad argument that the Chief Justice was talking about, that we have a man who drives in a car from Baltimore to rob a bank in Washington and the U.S. Attorney in Washington gives him a piece of paper which says, I will not prosecute you for this now or in the future, and suddenly the U.S. Attorney in Baltimore prosecutes it.
Are you saying that that is barred or not barred?
That's the broad argument.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: Well, under several--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Or are you making a narrow argument?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --Under several circuits' law--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well, I'm just asking you your position on that.
Can the -- does this piece of paper from the U.S. Attorney in Washington bar prosecution by the U.S. attorney in Baltimore?
Yes or no?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --I have a principal position and I have a back-up position.
My principal position is yes, it does, for the reason that I gave to the Chief Justice.
To the extent that there is skepticism--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: It does bar?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --It does.
The full rule is that the bar is only as to the office that -- that executes the agreement.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Counsel, could I ask you could a 1983 or I guess Bivens action be brought against Ms. Watson?
The defendant, you know, it turns out he's not guilty and he thinks there was malice.
Could he bring a Bivens action against her?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, I have not thought about that question.
I am completely clear as to your -- the question that you asked to Mr. Long, which is does she have Brady obligations.
She does have Brady obligations.
She was held to Brady obligations.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: She's a State actor.
She's acting on behalf either of the United States or the District of Columbia.
Therefore, she can be sued directly and be personally liable.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: She -- it is absolutely right that she is a State actor for constitutional purposes.
And she was treated as such throughout this litigation.
To go back to Justice Breyer's point -- may I?

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, briefly.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: Justice Breyer's question, the Chief Justice's question: Even circuits that apply a default rule whereby the government is the entire government and there needs to be limiting things in the agreement, I think if you look at this agreement you will find those limiting things, both in the cross-outs in the caption and in the particular promises that the United States Government has made, which applies really only to the United States Attorney's Office.
Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Thank you, General.
Ms. Frankfurt, you have 7 minutes remaining.

turn.speaker: jaclyn_s_frankfurt
turn.label: Ms. Jaclyn S. Frankfurt
turn.text: Thank you.

I just want to say in response both to -- to Mr. Long's comments, that a lack record as to what actually occurred or the general comment, about whether or not Ms. Watson was treated as a State actor -- I actually think there is a -- a decent record in this case that what occurred was not a motion to request the court to issue a show cause, but in fact, a -- a motion that requested -- that triggered a ministerial act, which was an act -- which was used as a charging document, which the judge believed she had no discretion, and the Assistant Attorney General, who was representing the Petitioner, believed she had no discretion to control, and Ms. Watson was treated as bringing the action on her own behalf.
That's what the lower court held as a factual matter, and I think it is quite supported by the record.

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: Can I ask you this: The District of Columbia Court of Appeals said we are satisfied that no objectively reasonable person could understand that Mr. Robertson's plea agreement bound Ms. Watson and precluded her contempt proceeding against Mr. Robertson.
If we accept that, is there any other issue in this case?

turn.speaker: jaclyn_s_frankfurt
turn.label: Ms. Jaclyn S. Frankfurt
turn.text: If you -- yes.
The issue is whether she could constitutionally bring the case on her own.

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: And did you preserve that?

If -- if Mr. -- Mr. Robertson had said, I understand this only means that I am not going to be charged with a -- a criminal offense by the United States Attorney's Office for the District of Columbia, and it has no application to this civil contempt proceeding.

turn.speaker: jaclyn_s_frankfurt
turn.label: Ms. Jaclyn S. Frankfurt
turn.text: We absolutely raise that because our argument from -- from the very beginning was she can't constitutionally be representing herself in this proceeding.
If this is happening constitutionally, she represents the United States, and if she represents the United States, then our plea agreement bars it because our plea agreement was with the government.
It indicated the government will not -- will not pursue, and any reasonable person in a--

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: But that's a separate question.
So the first question is: What was agreed to under the plea agreement, right?

turn.speaker: jaclyn_s_frankfurt
turn.label: Ms. Jaclyn S. Frankfurt
turn.text: --Yes, and at the time that we signed the plea agreement, there was no precedent for the notion of a private person bringing a criminal action in her own name, interest and on her own behalf.
No one would have contemplated that such a thing was constitutional, because you know, back until appeals of felonies--

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: Just so I understand what is before us, you preserve -- you saying -- you are saying you preserve the issue that even if your client fully understood that this plea agreement had no application to a criminal contempt proceeding, he preserved the argument that he could contest the criminal contempt proceeding on the ground that it would be unconstitutional?

turn.speaker: jaclyn_s_frankfurt
turn.label: Ms. Jaclyn S. Frankfurt
turn.text: --I'm sorry.
I am not -- I am not sure that I'm understanding, or that my words haven't been misinterpreted.
It's certainly not the case that when my -- that the reasonable interpretation of that plea agreement was that it wouldn't apply to a criminal contempt proceeding.
The only--

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: No, I understand that.
I understand there's the contract issue.
But did you -- in the lower court, did you argue even if he gave that up, under the plea agreement, the criminal contempt proceeding still could not be brought?

turn.speaker: jaclyn_s_frankfurt
turn.label: Ms. Jaclyn S. Frankfurt
turn.text: --Even if he gave up the right of a private person to prosecute on her own behalf?
Any agreement--

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: Even if he didn't get that -- a bar to that under the plea agreement, the contempt proceeding would still be barred for some other reason?
Did you make that argument?

turn.speaker: jaclyn_s_frankfurt
turn.label: Ms. Jaclyn S. Frankfurt
turn.text: --I am not sure that I can answer that we did, because I am not sure that I -- I understand the question.
I -- I know that we did make the argument that it could only have lawfully been brought on behalf of the sovereign, and that the sovereign was the United States.
And so our view was if this Court views it the way the lower court did, which was as an action between private parties, then it's unconstitutional under Gompers.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You did raise, undoubtedly you say, the point that the only way in which she could be the prosecutor was as an agent of the United States?

turn.speaker: jaclyn_s_frankfurt
turn.label: Ms. Jaclyn S. Frankfurt
turn.text: Absolutely.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And that it was unconstitutional for her to -- to represent herself.

turn.speaker: jaclyn_s_frankfurt
turn.label: Ms. Jaclyn S. Frankfurt
turn.text: Absolutely.
I think we wrote the word, you know,
"whoever stands in the well of the courtroom, it doesn't matter who that person is; that person represents the sovereign. "
That's the only constitutional way.
If it's viewed that way, it's barred by the plea agreement.
If it's not viewed that way, as the lower court construed the local statute to permit, then Gompers v. Buck's Stove does -- there is no authority there to impose a criminal penalty.
We would ask the Court to reverse.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Thank you, counsel.
The case is submitted.
